{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3755693,"name":"","username":"pigrammer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/pigrammer/{size}/234083_2.png","created_at":"2025-10-05T14:28:19.924Z","cooked":"

Per Practicing At Home | FIRST FRC Radio, it’s possible to connect directly to the VH-109 acting as an access point from a laptop capable of WiFi 6E:

image768×576 84.2 KB

My laptop (a Lenovo X1 Carbon 11th Gen running Windows 11 Pro) is capable of Wi-Fi 6E, as confirmed by netsh wlan show drivers:

Interface name: Wi-Fi

    Driver                    : Intel(R) Wi-Fi 6E AX211 160MHz
    Vendor                    : Intel Corporation
    Provider                  : Intel
    Date                      : 5/29/2025
    Version                   : 23.140.2.1
    INF file                  : oem35.inf
    Type                      : Native Wi-Fi Driver
    Radio types supported     : 802.11b 802.11g 802.11n 802.11a 802.11ac 802.11ax
    FIPS 140 mode supported   : Yes
    802.11w Management Frame Protection supported : Yes
    Hosted network supported  : No
    Authentication and cipher supported in infrastructure mode:
                                Open             None
                                Open             WEP-40bit
                                Open             WEP-104bit
                                Open             WEP
                                WPA-Enterprise   TKIP
                                WPA-Enterprise   CCMP
                                WPA-Personal     TKIP
                                WPA-Personal     CCMP
                                WPA2-Enterprise  TKIP
                                WPA2-Enterprise  CCMP
                                WPA2-Personal    TKIP
                                WPA2-Personal    CCMP
                                Open             Vendor defined
                                WPA3-Personal    CCMP
                                Vendor defined   Vendor defined
                                WPA3-Enterprise 192 Bits GCMP-256
                                OWE              CCMP
                                WPA3-Enterprise  CCMP
    Number of supported bands : 3
                                2.4 GHz [ 0 MHz - 0 MHz]
                                5 GHz [ 0 MHz - 0 MHz]
                                6 GHz [ 0 MHz - 0 MHz]
    IHV service present       : Yes
    IHV adapter OUI           : [00 00 00], type: [00]
    IHV extensibility DLL path: C:\WINDOWS\System32\DriverStore\FileRepository\netwtw6e.inf_amd64_a60cc63dd820d04f\IntelIHVRouter14.dll
    IHV UI extensibility ClSID: {00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}
    IHV diagnostics CLSID     : {00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}
    Wireless Display Supported: Yes (Graphics Driver: Yes, Wi-Fi Driver: Yes)

However, when the access point radio is turned on, the network is not visible in the Wi-Fi network list; additionally, even when I add the network manually as a known network, it still does not work. (Perhaps I have the wrong SSID? I’ve tried 246, FRC246, and FRC-246 and none of them seem to work. I’ve confirmed I do have the correct password).

Obviously this isn’t important but it would make some things more convenient as well as being pretty cool if I could get it to work.

There was a thread about issues with Intel drivers and the VH109 at

VH-109 Radio as an access point Control System
We have a pair of the new VH-109 radios. One is on the robot and one is configured as an access point. One of our laptops is Wi-Fi 7 capable (which includes Wi-Fi 6E obviously). The VH-109 radio on the robot connects to the VH-109 configured as an access point and if the laptop is connected to the AP via an ethernet cable everything works great. However, we want the laptop to connect to the AP via Wi-Fi. No matter what we did, the laptop could not see the VH-109 AP. Turns out to be a probl…

Thanks, I’d tried looking for previous threads but could not find any that helped me. It seems I have the same Intel Wi-Fi chip as @Ryan_Blue so hopefully his method works for me.

@kiettyyyy is there any chance this could be added to the documentation so that anyone looking for it in the future can find it more easily?

EDIT: Sorry for the ping, I see now that the Firmware Changelog for 1.2.3 says:

Added Reduced Neighbor Report (RNR) information element (IE) to the 2.4 GHz SSID enabling client devices without standards-based FILS support to connect to the 6 GHz SSID (Behavior -not a bug - discovered by FRC Team 1425 and Tim Bennington-Davis)

So that shouldn’t be necessary. I thought the radio was updated to the latest version but I guess it must not have been.

On the AP, do you have the 2.4 GHz DIP enabled? (this switch will be deprecated in releases 2.0 and up)

You should at least see the 2.4 GHz SSID which will have “FRC-” prepended to the SSID.

Make sure to powercycle the AP after flipping the switch.

you really don’t need to do any of that. if you have an AP capable of Wifi using the 6GHz band, then you can keep your radio (VH109) as just the client (reprogram it to match your Wifi AP’s information). And chances are your AP wifi can do all 3 band and then you just need to connect you DS to that AP. Just need to make sure you understands some basic IP and configure the AP network side appropriately.
